perturbation.original_text: eDiets agrees that it will respond in a timely manner to be agreed upon by the parties to all reasonable requests made by Women.com or its agents for updated eDiets Content and refreshing of eDiets Content for the Women.com Sites.
perturbation.changed_text: eDiets agrees that it will respond to requests made by Women.com or its agents for updated eDiets Content and refreshing of eDiets Content for the Women.com Sites within 72 hours.
perturbation.explanation: By mandating a 72-hour response time for content updates, the modified text may not comply with California Labor Code Section 925 which protects employees residing in California from having to abide by employer regulations that violate the law of their state. If an employee of eDiets is working from California, this 72-hour deadline may be considered unduly restrictive and not reasonably accommodated to their rights under state law.

perturbation.original_text: Women.com, in its sole discretion, may withdraw specific or general permission to use the Women.com Marks upon seventy-two (72) hours written notice to eDiets. Upon expiration of such notice period, eDiets shall immediately discontinue use of the applicable Women.com Marks.
perturbation.changed_text: Women.com, in its sole discretion, may withdraw specific or general permission to use the Women.com Marks upon twenty-four (24) hours written notice to eDiets. Upon expiration of such notice period, eDiets shall immediately discontinue use of the applicable Women.com Marks.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for trademark usage withdrawal to 24 hours may contradict general contract law principles requiring reasonable notice. California law, where the contract is enforced, implies a covenant of good faith and fair dealing in every contract. A 24-hour notice might be deemed unreasonable, especially considering the potential disruption to eDiets' marketing and branding efforts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Civil Code Section 1655 - Implied Stipulations and Good Faith

perturbation.original_text: Within fifteen (15) days of receipt by Receiving Party of a written request from the Disclosing Party for the return of Confidential Information, all Disclosing Party's Confidential Information and all copies thereof in Receiving Party's possession or control shall be returned to Disclosing Party or destroyed by Receiving Party at Disclosing Party's instruction.
perturbation.changed_text: Within five (5) days of receipt by Receiving Party of a written request from the Disclosing Party for the return of Confidential Information, all Disclosing Party's Confidential Information and all copies thereof in Receiving Party's possession or control shall be returned to Disclosing Party or destroyed by Receiving Party at Disclosing Party's instruction.
perturbation.explanation: Shortening the timeframe for returning confidential information to 5 days might conflict with the principle of 'reasonable time' for compliance, particularly under California law. Depending on the volume and nature of confidential information, 5 days might be insufficient, potentially leading to breach of contract disputes if compliance within that timeframe is unfeasible.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Civil Code Section 1657 - Time of Performance of Contract
